definition:
A **Fredholm operator** is a bounded operator between Banach spaces that
has a finite dimensional kernel and cokernel (and closed range).
Equivalently, it is invertible modulo compact operators. That is, if
$F\colon X \to Y$ is a Fredholm operator between two vector spaces $X$
and $Y$, then there exists a bounded operator $G\colon Y \to X$ such
that
$$GF-{\mathord{\mathrm{1\!\!\!\:I}}}_X \in {\mathbb{K}}(X), \quad FG-{\mathord{\mathrm{1\!\!\!\:I}}}_Y \in {\mathbb{K}}(Y),$$
where ${\mathbb{K}}(X)$ denotes the space of compact operators on $X$.
(Another way to say this is that $F$ is invertible in the Calkin
algebra). The set of Fredholm operators $\{F\colon X \to X\}$ is an open
subset of the Banach algebra of bounded operators $\{T\colon X \to X\}$.

If $F$ is Fredholm then so is its adjoint, $F^*$. If
$T \in {\mathbb{K}}(X,Y)$ is a compact operator then $F+T$ is also
Fredholm.
